awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Personalized Systems for Wayfinding for First Responders
awd_abstract_narration:
First responders face serious risks when responding to emergencies, and disorientation induced by complex building features is a major cause of injuries. In order to successfully navigate complex, dangerous buildings during a crisis, first responders need to build accurate spatial memories of unfamiliar spaces in a timely manner. This requires retention and processing of a large amount of information such as maps and verbal instructions. An apparent gap between the enormous information processing needs during a mission and the limited processing capacity of people creates a potentially fatal situation in emergency wayfinding. This project will contribute to the NSF's Big Idea "Harnessing Data for 21st Century Science and Engineering" by conducting fundamental research in information processing and engineering in the field of disaster management. This project will test the theoretical foundation of personalized wayfinding information systems that can effectively minimize the cognitive load of first responders on the individual level. This scientific research contribution thus supports NSF's mission to promote the progress of science and to advance our national welfare. In this case, the benefits will be insights to improve emergency response wayfinding, which will save lives and potentially reduce economic losses during disasters. 

This project has three interdependent scientific objectives. First, the research quantifies the structured relationship between spatial information and different forms of cognitive load in wayfinding tasks. Spatial information for wayfinding will be categorized and measured using semantic metrics; then a quantitative model of the relationship between spatial information and cognitive load will be examined. Second, the research explores cognitive resilience that helps identify and prevent an abrupt drop in wayfinding performance. Virtual Reality (VR) based multi-mission experiments are performed to examine the hypothetical nonlinearity of the relationship between cognitive load and wayfinding performance. Third, the research evaluates the effectiveness of personalized wayfinding information system in simulated mission tasks. A holistic VR experiment is performed to compare the new personalized system against the current universal spatial information systems. The outcome of the scientific investigation includes an adaptive wayfinding information system that dynamically tailors the way spatial information is presented based on the real-time cognitive load of individual first responders, measured by a set of neurobiological and physiological metrics. The project will immediately impact first responders primarily firefighters for their missions.  A number of collaborative outreach activities are planned between two project sites: Texas A&M University and Northeastern University. These include advancing VR technologies for STEM education, integrating the research outcomes to curriculum development at both institutions, and developing a free online course and open-source project for general public access.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this research is to test the theoretical foundation of a personalized spatial information system (PSIS) for first responders in emergency indoor wayfinding, which dynamically tailors the way spatial information is presented based on real-time cognitive load at the individual level. To achieve this goal, this research has developed a series of Virtual Reality models to simulate emergency scenarios where first responders need to perform search and rescue tasks. The models are equipped with sensors and algorithms to sense the real-time cognitive load of first responders. Then, a set of large scale human-subject experiments were performed with college students (n>200) and first responders (n=91) to collect data for modeling the relationship between wayfinding information and cognitive load. The main outcomes and findings are: (1) the data shows that there is a strong relationship between wauyfinding information (landmarks, routes, and maps in different formats) and different types of cognitive load. This finding sets the foundation for an intelligent wayfinding information system for controlling first responders' cognitive load by changing and adjusting the contents and formats of wayfinding information; (2) neuroimaging technologies along with machine learning, can help predict real-time cognitive load, and indicate what types of cognitive load are increasing. Increased cognitive load does not necessarily mean increased risks. Our system and method can differentiate the "good" cognitive load and "bad" cognitive load for a more effective intervention in emergency wayfinding; (3) an adaptive wayfinding information system that adjusts information automatically based on the measure of cognitive load outperforms other methods in both performance and cognitive functions. Our final user study compared three wayfinding information systems: control, self-control, and automatic (i.e., adaptive). Under the control condition (?cont?), all UI elements were permanent and could not be removed. Under the self-control condition (?self?), participants could remove any UI element as they wanted. And under the automatic condition (?auto?), UI elements were adjusted based on the real-time measures of the cognitive load.  The result shows that auto method could significantly improve both the wayfinding performance, and the ability to identify and mark hazards.  There are several important findings. First, the adaptive wayfinding system that automatically adjusts UI based on cognitive load can generally improve performance and reduce cognitive load. Second, we found that none of the UI solutions could work for everyone. Our Cognitive analysis system-based ?auto? method worked for 38.7% of the first responder population. The performance data also shows that for this group of people, our method could substantially improve their wayfinding performance, to a level that was even better that the other group of people. Last, the 38.7% of first responders whose cognitive load was reduced when using our system reported that they felt the environment of the building was difficult, and the procedure of search target in a multi-story building was complex. It may suggest that our system and method work for those who are challenged by the lack of spatial ability.

This project is expected to advance first responder communications and operations by investigating methods and systems that help effectively communicate wayfinding information while maintaining cognitive load at a healthy level in emergency wayfinding. According to the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA), failure of the emergency response team to timely and accurately familiarize with the affected environment is a major cause of casualties and property destruction. It also accounts for 43.6% of firefighters? injuries. Another challenge of firefighters? safety is the disorientation in retreat, i.e., finding the way out. While traditional navigation techniques, such as the L.A.S.T. technique which uses rope for navigation, has been criticized for its inefficiency, new solutions are of low resolution (e.g. GPS) or economically infeasible (e.g. Wi-Fi, LEBluetooth based positioning technologies). In current practice, firefighters still heavily rely on the cognitive maps (the mental representation of the environment) for wayfinding. The success of this project will provide an integrated solution for first responders to improve their wayfinding performance. While the innovative sensing technologies will monitor multiple physical, psychological and ergonomic parameters, the informatics processing functions will real-time analyze collected sensing data and present information for individual firefighters on the adaptive UI. The nowcasting power of the system, accompanying the intuitive UI, will play a critical role in first responders? communications and operations in their missions. Beyond that, tailored information will be stored and analyzed to guide training and promote individual growth of the first responders.
